newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai T-bill repo rates end down, spots mixed.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai T-bill repo rates end down, spots mixed.

text.p: Contracts on the treasury bill repurchase market in Shanghai closed mostly down on Monday due to a weak market trend on the domestic A share markets over the past few sessions, traders said.

But early-maturing contracts edged down while remaining at high levels due to two new listings on the Shanghai's A share market on Monday and Tuesday, they said. Petroleum Long Chang (Group) Co was listed on Monday and Qinghai Tongren Aluminium Industrial will make debut on Tuesday.
The annual rate for the most active seven-day contract edged down to 11.65 percent from 11.70 percent last Friday.
Combined turnover of the six-contract market rose to 8.25 million lots from 7.92 million.
One lot is 1,000 yuan face value of treasury bills.
"Some big institutions have reduced their borrowing on the repo market since the A share market began to show signs of weakness late last week," said one trader.
"In addition, some institutions borrowed money last week to prepare for new issues and listings this week," he said.
Traders said the rates were likely to move up in the next few days.
